Authors:
Jakub Barylski, François Enault, Bas E. Dutilh, Jochen
Klumpp, Rob Lavigne, Matthew B. Sullivan, Pakorn Aiewsakun, Johannes
Wittmann, Igor Tolstoy, Margo B.P. Schuller, Robert A Edwards, Annika
Gillis, Petar Knezevic, Mart Krupovic, Jens H. Kuhn, Hanna M. Oksanen,
Ho Bin Jang, Peter Simmonds, James Rodney Brister, Andrew M. Kropinski,
Evelien Adriaenssens
Title:
Analysis of Spounaviruses as a Case Study for the Overdue
Reclassification of Tailed Phages
Keywords:
Caudovirales; Herelleviridae; spounavirus; phylogenetics;
phylogenomics; virus classification; virus taxonomy
Abstract:
It is almost a cliché that tailed bacteriophages are the
most abundant and diverse viruses in the world. Yet, their taxonomy
still consists of a single order - Caudovirales, composed of just four
families: Myoviridae, Siphoviridae, Podoviridae, and the newly described
Ackermannviridae family. In recent years this morphology-based
classification scheme has started to crumble, undermined by the constant
flood of phage sequences, revealing that tailed phages are even more
genetically diverse than once thought. This prompted us (the Bacterial
and Archaeal Viruses Subcommittee of the International Committee on
Taxonomy of Viruses, ICTV) to consider overall reorganization of phage
taxonomy. In this study, we used a wide range of complementary methods 
including comparative genomes, core genome analysis and marker gene
phylogenetics  to show that the group of Bacillus phage SPO1-related
viruses previously classified into the Spounavirinae subfamily is
clearly distinct and its diversity deserves the rank of an autonomous
family. Thus, we propose to remove them from the Myoviridae family and
create “Herelleviridae”  a new taxon with the same rank. In the process
of the taxon evaluation we explored the feasibility of different
demarcation criteria and critically evaluated the usefulness of our
methods for phage classification. The convergence of results, drawing a
consistent and comprehensive picture of a new family with associated
subfamilies, regardless of method demonstrates that the tools applied
here are particularly useful in phage taxonomy. We are convinced that
creation of this novel family is a crucial milestone towards much-needed
re-classification in the Caudovirales order.
